page.title: 17ABRO EXPERIMAENTAL STATION
page.content: BLYTHBANK FARM BELONGS TO THE ANIMAL BREEDING RESEARCH ORGANISATION. IT IS A HIGH-LYING EXPOSED FARM OF 521 HECTARES, 35 KM SW OF EDINBURGH. THE SOIL IS MOSTLY OLD RED SANDSTONE WITH PEAT IN SOME AREAS. ABOUT 410 HECTARES ARE IN SEMI-PERMANENT GRASSLAND USED FOR GRAZING. HAY AND SILAGE. GRASS MIXTURE SEEDS ARE OF RYEGRASS, TIMOTHY GRASS AND WHITE CLOVER. THERE ARE ABOUT 69 HECTARES OF ROUGH GRAZING, WOODLANDS, ROADS AND BUILDINGS. SOME 40 HECTARES ARE CROPED AT PRESENT, WITH OATS, RAPE OR POTATOES, THE LATTER GROWN ON AN EXPERIMENTAL BASIS BY THE SCOTTISH & CAMBRIDGE PLANT BREEDERS. THE FARM DOES RESEARCH WITH CATTLES AND SHEEP, USING MANY DIFFERENT BREEDS. THE FARM CONSISTS OF A MANAGER WITH ABOUT 20 WORKERS INVOLVED IN THE CATTLE, SHEEP AND FARMIND SECTIONS, AND HOSTEL CARE.
